_items.body: “Wow! What a perfect color match. I mean, these two prints are identical!” Well, if you’ve ever had a customer tell you that, you are very-very lucky. If you yourself have said that, you probably weren’t looking close enough. Instead, more than likely, you hoped that your client would accept the output as “close enough” or that your supplier would deliver your job and that it would be close enough. Well, why can’t our color be perfect? Why is an exact color match often such a difficult goal to achieve? Why doesn’t color management just work?

In this course you’re going to learn what color management is, how it works, and what you need to do to take control of your color output and quality. You’ll learn about all of the important terms we use in the field of color management including what they mean along with important details that can impact your or your customer’s acceptance of your final output.

body: By the end of this course, you will be able to:

_items.title: explain key concepts such as color space, gamut, and device dependent color
select important settings including correct ICC Profiles, rendering intents, and black point compensation
explain the importance of and difference between calibration and profiling
properly select the appropriate specification for your color output
choose the proper settings on your spectrophotometer as well as the proper viewing conditions for your final output

title: Course Objectives

_items.text: a process used in the graphic arts to guarantee perfect color reproduction
a process used to ensure that images appear on different devices in a consistent way
a process for converting black & white images into color images
the process of selecting only reproducible colors

title: #Pre-Assessment MCQ Question 20#

body:
Hi there! Welcome to this, the first module in the color management fundamentals course. In this module you will gain an understanding of exactly what color management is. Now, color management is a process, it's not a task. It's not I calibrate my monitor or you calibrate your monitor, you build a profile, or calibrate an output device. It's a number of tasks all linked together to form a complete process, something that we also call a work flow. It's making sure that the image that comes off your camera looks accurate on your monitor, what you see on your monitor is what I see on my monitor, what we see on our monitors either matches what comes out of our output device, or what comes out of the output device matches another output device or simulates the output from another device.


The process of color management is meant to ensure color fidelity between these devices, to make sure the color matches across all these devices. A problem is that color management is limited by the devices. All of these devices can't give us the same color. Your monitor might be different than my monitor; different manufacturers, different technology. Our output devices are different. Maybe we have different media on the same type of output device or I may have a toner output device you may have been aqueous inkjet printer. Someone else has a UV inkjet printer and the colorants are different, or a printing press using traditional inks. All the colorants are different, all the technologies are different and all the capabilities are different. Color management understands this and it takes into consideration the limitations of each of these different technologies.


I'm going to borrow concepts from Steve Upton from Chromix. He came up with a kind of a simplified explanation of what color management it. It's an idea where color management is like making toast. How on earth is it like making toast? Well, imagine you and I each have toasters. Our toasters have knobs on them that we can set from one to ten. You toast 10 slices of bread and I toast 10 slices of bread. Now our toasters might be completely different brands or maybe even the same brand, maybe one right after the other off the assembly line, but they're probably not going to give us exactly the same toast. If we look at this example and we line up the toast, your toast and my toast, well, they don't match. With both of our toaster settings at 3 the toast doesn't look the same or have the same density. The toast is different.


Now, what we can do is to slide the sets of toast back and forth until we line them up, so that we can see that the densities across from each other now match. We now know the limitation, or the common toast density if you will, that we can get between our two toasters. One toaster toasts a little lighter, one toasts a little darker, but we now know what we can get from each other. We also know that if one toaster is set with a setting of 3, that the other toaster needs to be set to 5 in order to match the toast density.

We could measure all the toast from one toaster and store those density values in a file, and we could do the same with the other toaster, and then we could possibly automate the process. Maybe set up some kind of a mechanism that when I push button 5 on my toaster your toaster automatically goes to setting up 3 and now what I ordered from you is what you deliver to. And I am now happy!


Now this all works well until one of us changes to whole wheat bread, which is no different than when we changed the media on out output device. Now we're not going to get the same output and we're not going to get the same density and there is going to be an impact because of the media change, or if we change ink, or change any one of a number of variables. Then we need to our re-measure and rebuild that file in order to continue the process.


That is a simplified form that is what color management is. In toast color management we really only care about density. In our world of graphic arts, color management also takes into consideration the color, the saturation that he will cover in a little bit, for all of the various colors that were trying to reproduce. But in a nutshell, that's what color management is. Color management is like making toast.
title: #Module 1 Video Script#

instruction: Take a moment to review these questions!

_items.title: What is color management?
_items.body: A process,or collection of tasks, meant to ensure color fidelity and accuracy between multiple devices such as cameras, monitors, and output devices.#

_items.title: What is color fidelity?
_items.body: Color fidelity is the accurate reproduction of color on one device when compared to that of another device or to the original.

_items.title: What are device limitations?
_items.body: Device limitations are issues that impact the reproduction of color. For example, an inkjet printer may print on a media that cannot absorb a large quantity of ink and therefore cannot reproduce certain saturated colors accurately.

title: #Module 1 Review#

body: Color management is best defined as:

_items.text: A method used to calibrate output devices
A system used to ensure color fidelity between devices
A system used to ensure that all colors reproduce exactly the same on any device
a process used to build ICC Profiles

title: #Module 1 Knowledge Check#

body: An important limitation of color management is:

_items.text: Not all devices can reproduce all colors accurately
Most spot colors cannot be reproduced on most output devices
There is no scale for determining color accuracy

title: #Module 1 Knowledge Check Question 2#

body:
In this module you will gain an understanding of the meaning of color space and gamut, and by the end you will be able to explain one of the key concepts of color management: L*a*b* color space. The term color space refers to an idea where color is a 3-dimensional object. This might sound a bit strange to you but it's an idea that allows color management to operate and ensures that computers can perform tasks such as interpolation when you are scaling images, adding or subtracting pixels, creating smooth gradients, and other important tasks.


What you see here is a common illustration of color space. In real life it is never this perfectly round sphere, but I'll use this to explain the basic concepts. This color space might represent a monitor, an output device, a camera, printing press, really any device we might use in the graphic arts industry. It also doesn't matter whether the device is an RGB device like a camera or a monitor or CMYK device like a printer or a printing press. Every color that our device can capture, display, or reproduce can be located somewhere within this ball of color. White is at the very top and black is at the very bottom. Right through the middle from the North Pole to the South Pole is our grayscale. Halfway up would be approximately middle gray. As we move away from the central axis we start to pick up color and our grays are no longer neutral. The farther out we get the more saturation we get in our color. And, if you look, we've got the colors really set up in a circle around the center and color can actually could be considered to have a direction. Yellow is one direction and in the exact opposite direction would be blue.


If this were an RGB color space we would be dealing with light, and it's called the additive primary system, where the more color, the more light we add, the lighter things get. If this were a CMYK device we would be using the subtractive primary system where the more ink or toner we add the darker things get.


A key color space is the L*a*b* color space. You might have seen this listed on the menu in Photoshop or other application. L*a*b* color space contains all of the color that we can see. That's why it is a key element in making sure the color management works. In L*a*b* color space the L* channel is the location, from top to bottom of the color. The higher the color the lighter the color. The lower the color the darker the color. Then, rather than amounts of RGB light or CMYK toner used in other color space models, it uses the a* and b* portion of the L*a*b* color space to locate the exact color inside this 3-D ball. a* is the red half or cyan half of color space and b* is the yellow and blue portion of color space. So L*a*b* really uses a form of triangulation if you will. It's kind of like a GPS for color for our computers.


All of the color the device can make available to us, all of the color in its unique color space, is referred to as its gamut. The more color a device can capture or reproduce the larger its color space and the larger its gamut. Here you can see an actual 3-D rendering of a color space. This is a plot for U. S. Web Coated SWOP, a very common CMYK color space available in most of our applications. Now, if I compare this color space to the color space for Fogra 52, you can see that Fogra 52 is larger, meaning that it contains colors not available in the SWOP color space. This means that the Fogra 52 gamut is larger than the SWOP gamut. And if we were to compare this to the Adobe RGB color space, one of the most common RGB color spaces, you can see that the Adobe gamut is much larger. To the graphic artist, that means that there are colors that you can capture with your camera, which could use the Adobe RGB color space, colors that you cannot reproduce on a device that has the capabilities or gamut of the Fogra 52 device, and the Fogra 52 device can print colors that you cannot print on the SWOP output device.


Back to our toast illustration in the last module, we use the difference in color spaces to calculate the common areas that we can reproduce. We understand the gamut of our output devices and we can work with them and work with color using something called rendering intent when we do color transforms, a topic that will be covered in future modules.

instruction: Take a moment to review these questions!

_items.title: What is Color Space?
_items.body: Color space is a method of displaying the color that a device can reproduce as a 3-dimensional model.  This model is used by computers to perform tasks such as color interpolation and color conversions.
Gamut refers to all of the color that a given device can reproduce.  The more color that a device can reproduce, the larger its gamut.
_items.title: What is Gamut?

_items.body: L*a*b* is a specific color space that contains all of the color that can be seen with the human eye.
_items.title: What is L*a*b*?

title: #Module 2 Review#

title: #Module 2 Knowledge Check#

body: When we refer to the gamut of an output device, we are actually referring to:

_items.text: All spot colors that the device can reproduce
All of the colors that the device can reproduce
The capability of a device to product even gradations
The consistency of a device as measured over time

title: #Module 2 Knowledge Check Question 2#

body:
When you are finished with this module you will be able to explain how we define color accuracy and explain how color accuracy is quantified through something we called Delta- E.


To understand color accuracy we need to understand how color can be inaccurate. Color can be inaccurate because of an error in 1, 2, or even a combination of 3 reasons. The first is an error in what we call luminance or lightness. This is likely the easiest to understand. If we take a look at an image in adobe Photoshop, I can take the lightness slider and move it to the right or to the left and the entire image will get lighter or darker. Every pixel changes. What we're doing is, if you think back to our 3-dimensional color space model, is we're simply moving all these pixels higher or lower in 3-D color space making them lighter or darker.


The second reason a color can be inaccurate is because there is an error in chroma or saturation. Back to Photoshop, if I move the saturation slider to the right or left saturation increases the vibrancy of the colors or move them towards neutrality, making them more gray. Again here we are moving all the pixels towards the outside of color space. Remember, that's where saturated colors live, or moving them towards the middle which is where our grayscale lives.


The final reason for color inaccuracy is caused by an error in hue. This is much like looking at a box of crayons and selecting the wrong crayon out of the box. It's the easiest for most people to detect. They say that's the wrong color. It is supposed to be powder blue and is it a sky blue or robin's egg blue or a true blue. Again looking at our image in Photoshop one last time...


Now this is a little different because what we're doing when we move the hue slider is rapidly rotating these colors around in the 3-D color space. Remember I said color is a direction in the last module, where we have yellow in one area and blue in a different area. So, when we move the slider everything rotates around the central axis. It's interesting, if you move the slider all the way to the left, take a look at the image here, and if I move it all the way to the right, t's the same color! that's because we moved all these pixels around 360 degrees.


As explained earlier, an error in color can be caused because of an error in any one of or any combination of these 3 variables. When the color is not correct, when there is an error, we can actually measure that. We use something called a spectrophotometer. I'll talk about that in a future module, but we can use it to measure the color, and when we measure the color this device tells us the L*a*b* value of that color, where it's located in 3-D color space. Then, we look at a reference, or maybe a different measurement to find out where the color should be. Likely those are going to be two different locations in this 3-D color space. The farther apart those 2 locations are, the larger the color difference. If the colors are very close to each other, they may be close enough that we don't see the error.


We can actually apply a numerical value to the error to calculate a Delta-E value. We use this very complex formula, and luckily, our software does this for us so we don't have to go through this complex formula every time we want to determine what the Delta-E is. In determining Delta-E the calculation will give us a value, a numerical value. In our industry, the threshold for accurate color is considered to be 1.0. If the color difference is above 1.0, a trained eye should be able to determine or detect the difference. If it's below 1.0, a trained eye will likely not see a difference.


This formula is not perfect and we can actually see below Delta-E error values of 1.0 in grayscales for instance. We are very, very good at detecting that there's a color cast in our grayscales. But in some color areas, yellows greens for example, we might need larger than a Delta-E of 1.0 in order for us to detect the difference.


A key concept to calculate Delta-E is that it's the difference between 2 measurements. You can't take a single color and say what the Delta-E is for that color. It's what is the Delta-E of that color compared to another color.


In our world we often calculate average and peak Delta-Es. We will do a sampling of colors and say "on average, how do all of the colors off of my output device compare to those colors reproduced on a different output device". Then we might look at the peak, what's the worst color? How far off is the worst color? We're going to explore specifications later in this course, things like GRACoL and Fogra 51. The industry has specified Delta-E tolerances for a number of measurements. So we just measure the colors that are specified, calculate the differences, whether it's an average or a peak difference, and the calculated result will tell us whether or not we are within compliance and we should have good color. So that's a little bit about color space itself and color errors in Delta-E.
title: #Module 3 Video Script#

instruction: Take a moment to review these questions!

_items.title: How is color accuracy defined?
_items.body: Color accuracy is defined in the graphic arts industry by measuring a sample and a reference color with a spectrophotometer and using software to calculate the amount of color error.  This error is reported using a scale known as Delta-E.

Delta-E is a value obtained by calculating the difference between the L*a*b* values of two samples as measured with a spectrophotometer.  A Delta-E value of 1 usually indicates that a trained eye will be able to see a slight difference between the two samples.
_items.title: What is Delta-E?

_items.body: Color scientists are constantly working to improve the accuracy of Delta-E.
_items.title: What is Delta-E 2000?

title: #Module 3 Review#

body: Above this value, most trained graphic artists should be able to see a measured difference between two colors.
title: #Module 3 Knowledge Check#

body: What scale is used to report color accuracy?
title: #Module 3 Knowledge Check Question 2#

body:
In this module you will explore the concepts of device dependent and device independent color and find out how L*a*b* color space fits into this equation. Device dependent color is fairly easy to understand as it means exactly what the name says. The color you get depends upon the device. Imagine that you have two cameras and that they're aimed at an apple, in a studio under controlled lighting conditions. And now we photograph the apple on each camera, bring the 2 images into Photoshop, and were able to isolate a single pixel. We measure that pixel and we find that we get different RGB values. Why is that? Well our devices aren't perfect, manufacturing isn't perfect, the sensor on the camera is manufactured to specific tolerances but not exactly the same tolerance for each chip, the coating on the lenses might be different. There are a lot of variables that come into play. And therefore the pixel in our apple image is going to be slightly different on different devices.


Now imagine you have three different output devices. The three output devices might be the same output device with three different media types, or it might actually be three different output devices using the same media. But suppose we send that apple image to each of those three output devices or to the same output device changing media between each print. You likely will not get the same results. If we look at that pixel, we would actually need to come up with a different recipe and change the characteristics of the file to send to the output device or output devices in order to get that pixel to be the same color across the three different outputs.


How do we know it matches? Well we can measure the samples and if we could measure that specific pixel with a spectrometer, we would be able to get L*a*b* values. If you remember the discussion earlier L*a*b* essentially means what will it look like; what does that pixel look like to the human eye? Well, if the L*a*b* values are the same even though it took different CMYK recipes to Image that pixel, if L*a*b* values are the same it means that the color looks the same. L*a*b* color is said to be device independent. It assumes that everyone sees color in much the same way and therefore whose device we use, whose eyes are viewing the results, we will see the same results. The results are independent of an individual persons eyes. Since L*a*b* color space refers to what the eye sees, it is therefore classified as device independent color space.


So that is a little bit about the device dependent color, device independent color, and how we use L*a*b* values to determine whether we have a color match or not.
title: #Module 4 Video Script#

instruction: Take a moment to review these questions!

_items.body: Device-dependent color simply means that the amount of color that we can get from a device (e.g. camera, monitor, printer) depends upon the capability of the device itself.  As an example, if you change to a different media on your output device you may alter the device gamut, reducing the range of colors that can be reproduced.
_items.title: What is device-dependent color?
What is device-Independent color?
_items.body: Device-independent usually refers to L*a*b* color space, the color that can be seen by the human eye.

_items.title: How is device-dependent color addressed when reproducing color?
_items.body: When converting from one Device-dependent color space to another, the color values are almost always passed through a device independent color space (L*a*b*) to ensure that the final color remains as visually accurate as possible.

_items.text: reproducible on a standard printing press
able to be displayed on a color monitor
contained in the spot color libraries
that the human eye can see

title: #Module 4 Knowledge Check Question 2#

body:
Hi there! Welcome back! When you've completed this module you will not only be able to explain what rendering intents and black point compensation are, but you will be able to select the appropriate options whenever you need to within your software applications.


Imagine that this gamut represents one particular color space. It might be our camera color space, and we've captured a particular green pixel which is a very vivid green color. Now take a look at the gamut of a second device. This might be your output device. Notice that it has a much smaller gamut. Where does this green color exists in that output device? It doesn't. This green color is what we refer to as out of gamut for that output device. Well, what can I do? I can't say "well I just won't reproduce that green and I'll just leave blank paper"; I don't think my customer will be very happy if I do that, so I have to change the recipe of that green color. I have to make it some color of green that I can reproduce. How that recipe changes is defined by something that we call rendering intent. A rendering intent is a mathematical formula that deals with out of gamut colors and changes them, a process that we call re-mapping, so that they become in-gamut colors.


Take a look at this illustration and imagine that this is a top down view of our three dimensional color spaces, overlaid one on top of the other, again using this perfect sphere for demonstration purposes. It's not real life but, again, for illustration purposes it will work. You see we have six pixels plotted in this color space. Let's assume that these are yellow pixels and it's a bright Canary yellow. Pixels 1, 2, and 3 are within both gamuts which means they can be reproduced. Pixels 4, 5, and 6, however, are in my larger gamut color space but they aren't available in the smaller gamut. I need to do something to change those pixels in order to make them reproducible and when I do a conversion these rendering intents come into play.


The first rendering intent we're going to talk about is the perceptual, sometimes called the photographic rendering intent in your software. And the perceptual or photographic rendering intent understands relationships between pixels. It looks at all the pixels together with their relationships. What you see here in the illustration, pixel 6 is the farthest out pixel that I can't reproduce. When I apply this rendering intent it would move it to be the farthest out available, the most vivid, the most saturated yellow that I can reproduce. Now, pixel 5 is a little less saturated so it will become this pixel, also a little less saturated than pixel 6. Same with pixel 4. But notice that pixel 4 is now less saturated than pixel 3, so I have to re-map or change pixels 1, 2, and 3. They have to kind of move out of the way to make room for their neighbors, pixels 4, 5, and 6. You can see that all the pixels have now been moved. Here is the original location of the pixels, 4, 5, and 6 all move in, while 1, 2, and 3 move out of the way. Here are all the pixels now remapped. The relationships have stayed the same and that's why it's called the perceptual or the photographic intent. We kept the relationship so you even though we've changed every single pixel that image, you don't visually see the difference because everything has moved in relationship to each other.


The next rendering intent I want to talk about is colorimetric. There's actually 2 flavors but they both work in basically the same manner. Using colorimetric, all pixels are treated independently. The system doesn't care how close any one pixel is to another in color definition. It looks at this and says "Hey, pixels 1, 2, and 3, you can reproduce them! Don't change them at all. Pixels 4, 5, and 6, move them each the minimum amount you need in order to make them reproducible". So, pixels 4, 5, and 6, what happened? Because they're in a straight line towards the center of color space, they each move in and become the most saturated pixel that we can reproduce and now pixels 3, 4, and 5 become the same color and any gradition, any "drawing" any differentiation between those pixels is lost and we've introduced banding into our output.


Often, however, this is said to be the most accurate rendering intent. Why is that? Because it only moves pixels that need to be moved and it moves them each individually the minimum amount needed to be able to reproduce them. So by definition that's the most accurate because it introduces the least amount of change into the conversion. It is also the default rendering intent in most of our creative applications and our RIPs because it's the most accurate and because if it's the problem, if it's the wrong rendering intent, we're going to be able to see the incorrect results. Take a look at your saturated colors. Did you lose definition? If you lost definition, well you might want to switch to the perceptual or photographic rendering intent.


I said earlier that there are 2 different flavors of the colorimetric rendering intent. There's relative colorimetric and absolute colorimetric. Absolute colorimetric is only ever used in proof printing. Absolute colorimetric understands the white point of the media that the targets were printed on. We'll cover that when we talk about ICC profiles. Imagine that you want to simulate the output on your printer of an image that will be printed in the newspaper. For accuracy, we will want to simulate the color and the density of the newsprint, otherwise are proof will be very inaccurate. Selecting the absolute colorimetric rendering intent will accomplish this.


I like to tell people is if you absolutely have to get absolutely perfect color, within the capabilities of the output device, obviously you want to use absolute colorimetric and if you're looking for just relatively close, then select relative colorimetric.


The final rendering intent is saturation, also pretty easy to understand. Pixels 4, 5, and 6, move them the minimum amount you need to make them reproducible, Pixels 1, 2, and 3, move them outside towards the outside of color space. Remember, that's where more saturated colors live. So this makes all pixels reproducible and adds a little saturation to the mix. This rendering intent is rarely used in the graphic arts industry. It was originally named the business graphic rendering intent because it was intended for use with charts and graphics where we are only looking for brighter, more saturated colors.


Let's take a look at an image in Photoshop to see where absolute colorimetric comes into play. I will call up this image and I will selec newsprint for the simulation, and I'll turn on switch from absolute colorimetric to relative colorimetric. You can see that simulation of the newsprint coming into play and that's where this absolute colorimetric is used, It is basically used in the proofing arena.


Now let's turn our attention to black point compensation, also something that has to be selected in our software. Black point compensation is a little easier because it's either yes or no; it's either on or it's off. In most creative applications it's turned on by default and in RIPs it's normally off.


What black point compensation does is it compensates for the different capabilities of the contrast range of our output devices. Some devices have a much larger contrast range and can print much darker than others. If you turn black point compensation on it will take advantage of that or help to correct for that. If we have black point compensation turned on, and we have prepared an image for reproduction for inkjet, and then want to print this image in the newspaper, with black point compensation on it will compress the tonal range. The darkest area in the inkjet prepared image will become the darkest area in our newspaper and will keep all the total range. If I were to say no to black point compensation then I introduced banding, I collapse all of the tones in the shadow areas and I lose shadow detail.


If I'm going the other direction and I have an image that was prepared for newsprint and I printed it on an output device with a greater dynamic range and selected to not use black point compensation, however dark the darkest pixel is in my newsprint image is, that's how dark it will reproduce on my inkjet printer, and if you look at if you looked at the print, you may think that it does not look that good. It is, however, showing you what the image would look like when it is printed in the newspaper. It would be an accurate proof. If I turn black point compensation on, it will tend to expand the tonal range and take advantage of the fact that I have more contrast available in my inkjet printer.


One area where you might find the use of black point compensation to be especially useful is in the area of production printing. Take a look at this image in Photoshop and watch as I toggle black point compensation on and off. You'll notice that when black point compensation is on there is much-improved shadow detail in the dark areas of the bellows and in other dark areas. In production printing, turning on black point compensation might be useful to gain additional shadow detail. You would likely not use black point compensation in a proofing workflow because the systems that generate the final printing plates, final films, or even direct to pressed systems, very often do not have black point compensation as a capability. Therefore, if you had black point compensation turned on when you made proofs you would likely have more shadow detail than they might be able to hold on the press so you likely want to avoid using it in a proofing workflow.


It's important you understand these two concepts; the relative, absolute, and perceptual or photographic rendering intents and black point compensation, on or off. When I teach students these concepts, I would often ask them on the first day when they come in with their laptops, what rendering intent do they have selected. And they'd look at me like I was from another planet. "I don't know what you're talking about" they would say. "Okay," I'd say "relative color metric. Thank you. Do you have black point compensation on or off?" "I don't know what you mean" they would answer. I would say "on. Thanks, you" When they would ask what I was talking about, I would have them launch Photoshop and go to the color settings and take a look, and invariably they have relative colorimetric and black point compensation on selected. They would ask how I knew that and I would answer that "I knew that because you didn't." Because if you don't know about the settings or how to set the settings then you're leaving it up to an engineer to come up with the proper settings for you and you don't want to do that. You want to take control. You want to be able to make sure that the settings are correct for your particular application so that you do get the color that you want for your output.
title: #Module 5 Video Script#

instruction: Take a moment to review these questions!

_items.body: Rendering intents are mathematical formulas that are used when converting from one color space to another to address the issue where the source color space may have a larger gamut than the destination color space, and out-of-gamut colors need to be modified in order to reproduce them as accurately as possible.#
_items.title: What is a rendering intent?
What is black point compensation?
_items.body: Black point compensation is a feature available in our applications that can be used to compensate for the differences in dynamic range between different devices, since some devices can print darker than others.  It is often used to enhance shadow detail in production printing.

title: #Module 5 Review#

body: Rendering Intents are needed because of the difference between:
title: #Module 5 Knowledge Check#

body: In Adobe and most other creative applications Black Point Compensation is, by default:
title: #Module 5 Knowledge Check Question 2#

body:
In this module you will learn why color needs to be transformed from one color space to another and how this process can differ between a proofing workflow and a production workflow.


Whenever we convert color from one color space to another, we call that a color transform; we're transforming it from one color space into another. Probably one of the most common transforms is to convert from RGB to CMYK. Our output devices, for the most part, use cyan, magenta, yellow, and black color whether toner or ink. Images coming from digital cameras or from scanners are RGB, Well, RGB data cannot be sent directly to CMYK print heads, so it needs to be converted into the CMYK color space. But that's not the limit of doing transforms. You can have RGB to RGB, CMYK to CMYK, even CMYK back to RGB for different reasons. But the most common is from RGB to CMYK.


These transforms can be done within Photoshop. They can be done within the printing application or within the RIP that actually drives the output device. There are a number of different ways that you can do the actual transform. When you do the transform, this is when the rendering intent and black point compensation come into play. Which rendering intent you use and whether or not you use black point compensation will depend upon whether you're working with a production workflow or a proofing workflow. If you are making something that only needs to looks nice hanging on the wall and it is an RGB to CMYK transform, you would likely use the perceptual or the photographic rendering intent. CMYK to CMYK? Often you will use the relative colorimetric rendering intent. In production you would likely turn on black point compensation to get that extra shadow detail while, if you're doing a proofing workflow, black point compensation would likely be turned off. Printing to conform to a specification such as ISO coated or Fogra 39, SWOP, or GRACoL? In that case you will likely use absolute colorimetric if the media you're printing on is very different, for example is much brighter and much bluer, than absolute colorimetric would likely be the rendering intent you would select and you would not have black point compensation turned on.


So you have a number of different situations where you might do transforms a lot of different ways, each time using different rendering intents and black point compensation settings. hopefully you now have a fairly good understanding of where and how black point compensation and rendering intents are used.
title: #Module 6 Video Script#

instruction: Take a moment to review these questions!

_items.title: What is the difference between production printing and proofing?
_items.body: In production printing you are normally attempting to produce the best, most pleasing output possible.  In proofing, you are attempting to  ensure that the output looks like something else, often the same job printed on a printing press or matching to an industry specification such as Fogra 39 or GRACoL.

Often, the simplest reason is that the original file is in an RGB color space and needs to be converted the the CMYK color space used by the output device.  In addition, conversion sometimes needs to be done then performing color matching in a proofing workflow.
_items.title: Why does color need to be “converted”?

title: #Module 6 Review#

body: If you are performing a conversion from RGB to CMYK, the best choice for a Rendering Intent to use is probably:
title: #Module 6 Knowledge Check#

body: The Rendering Intent used to simulate the whitepoint of the reference or source material is:
title: #Module 6 Knowledge Check Question 2#

body:
Welcome back! When you finish this module you'll be able to explain the difference between calibration and profiling and explain how each activity impacts color reproduction.

Calibration and profiling are two separate tasks and there's a lot of misunderstanding out there. I've often heard people say well I'm going to calibrate my output device to match GRACoL. That's not really what you want to. Instead, you want to calibrate the output device to give you the most color that it possibly can. Then, we can use profiles to limit the output make a match some other look that you are trying to achieve.

Calibration actually physically changes the device, whether it's a monitor, a digital camera, or an output device. The intent is to match a device to itself over time. As a device drifts, we want to bring it back, and bring it back into a repeatable state so that when we reprint work today matches what we printed a few months ago. We are not giving out customer something one day and something completely different the next day.

Often, people have said that calibration is much like tuning a guitar. If a number of people in the same room have guitars but they're all out of tune, even if they precisely play the same song, it's not going to sound the same. But when those guitars are tuned then all the sudden there's harmony when we play. Everything sounds the same. Well that's the idea behind calibrating our devices. Get them repeatable, get them into a known state so we can predict what we're going to get.

The art of calibration or the task of calibration is really broken down into a number of different tasks. It is sometimes called linearization but linearization is really only one part of this task, one part calibration. If we look at digital cameras, calibration can be considered to be performed when you set the shutter speed, when you set the aperture, and, most importantly, when you white or gray balance your image. It's very important that you do a white or gray balance to make sure that the camera is in the proper configuration giving you the proper color

Now monitors you calibrate by setting the brightness, setting the contrast controls, and on higher end monitors, setting the white point. You can actually set the white point to be a particular, what we call color temperature. Is it to be a little bluish white, a little warm white, neutral white? What are you trying to get? When calibrating some monitors you can set those criteria.

Often however, when we're talk about calibration we're talking about output devices. To calibrate output devices we need to set the per channel limits. We don't want to waste ink or toner and there will be a point when we are. Laying more ink or more toner on the output material and we're not really gaining anything. We're not getting any saturation and now we're just wasting money. We also want per channel linearity, making sure that we get a nice even gradation from 0 to 100 percent. We don't want a system where from 0 to 50 there is hardly any change at all but from 50 to 60 is a night and day difference. It would be very difficult to color management system like that. We also want to set the total limit. Total limit of toner or of ink again goes back to not wasting money along with not blocking up our shadows. Often the total limits and per channel limits, especially on toner devices are factory set. At EFI we work with the manufacturers to build this in to the fiery software to make sure that per channel limits and total limits don't go beyond what they need to to. For ink jet printers it's really all on you. Using Fiery proServer or Fiery XF you take complete control over the total ink limit and per channel ink limit. We both still do the linearity however, making sure that we have a nice even gradation ramp. A fourth criteria that we want is to have a half-way decent gray balance. Gray balance does have to be perfect because the ICC profiles will take it the rest of the way. This is often done with output devices through the use of a RIP such as a Fiery.

Let's take a look first at the per channel limits. What we're looking at there again is on an aqueous inkjet printer, we want to make sure the media doesn't come out wet, or on a toner or a UV based output device we want to make sure that we're not wasting our pigments. For the per channel linearity we want to get a nice even ramp, a nice even gradation. We want to make sure that our highlights have good tone separation as do out shadows and that there's a nice even total ramp through the entire scale. The next is total ink limit. We want to make sure that output from out aqueous inkjet printer doesn't come out wet, and if it's toner or UV printer that we still get a gradation tones right up to what we consider the total ink limit, otherwise, again, we're losing shadow detail. Finally, we want a good gray balance. a good, not great, gray balance can be a little off through the entire total scale. Maybe it's a little warmer, a little cool, or it starts with one color and shifts to another color. Just a little bit. Again, this is not a big issue. What we want to make sure of is that we're seeing a different color for every 5 percent increase. That would not be good.

That is calibration. Next we move on to profiling. Profiling is done on top of or after calibration. Profiling is a process where we print a target, or we measure color patches on a monitor, or we photograph what is often called a color checker which has color patches on it. We know what the values are suppose to be, what the L*a*b* values are. In the case of output devices, we know what CMYK or RGB values we are sending to the output device. We print them and we measure them and we get L*a*b* values; what does that color look like when we printed it.

That's when an ICC profile is. An ICC profile is a link between recipes, RGB or CMYK values, and results. what does it look like in L*a*b* values. L*a*b* color space is the visual color space. L*a*b* is what's used when we do our color transforms.

Let's say we have an RGB image from a camera and we take one specific pixel. The ICC profile for that camera understands that a particular RGB value is supposed to give us a specific L*a*b* value. We then take that L*a*b* value from that profile and send it to the L*a*b* input portion of the media profile. This output profile takes the L*a*b* value, goes through its tables, and looks for a CMYK recipe that will get us the closest match back to that original pixel on our digital camera. That's the transform and that's where profiles come are used. The data is then sent through the calibration file to the output device to make sure that it's output on a device that's linear and doesn't over-ink.

Calibration and profiling work hand in hand. Calibration first give us the maximum color gamut we can. It sets the "golden stick in the ground" to make sure we can repeatedly come back to that known state, and then the profile, which is kind of a dictionary of color which translates from one color space to another, often from our RGB input to our CMYK output space.
title: #Module 7 Video Script#

instruction: Take a moment to review these questions!

_items.body: Calibration is a set of tasks used to ensure that we obtain the largest color gamut from our devices.  This physically changes how the device reproduces color.  On a monitor, this includes adjusting the brightness and contrast levels.  On an output device, it can include setting per-channel and total color limits and wellas linearity or evenness of gradations.
_items.title: What is calibration?
What is profiling?
_items.body: Profiling captures the capability of the device to reproduce color and saves it in what we refer to as an ICC Profile.  This profile does not change the device itself, but is used when performing color transforms from one color space to another.

title: #Module 7 Review#

body: Which process is performed regularly?
title: #Module 7 Knowledge Check#

body: Which process is performed regularly in order to bring a device back into compliance?
title: #Module 7 Knowledge Check Question 2#

body:
When you finish this module you'll be able to select proper settings for common black generation options as well as explain the concept of GCR.

We're going to take a little deeper dive into some of the common areas of what we call black generation settings for building ICC profiles. When you build a CMYK ICC profile you have to set black settings. Why don't you have to set black generation settings in an RGB profile? Because it has no black channel. But there is a black channel in a CMYK profile and you can do a number of things when you configure this black channel.

The reason we use black is that cyan, magenta, and yellow don't really make a good black on a press or many other output devices. By themselves, they don't really have enough density, they don't have enough saturation needed to create really deep rich black. Also, black ink and black toner are our friends. If we create neutrals out of just black we cut our cost because black can give us a higher density using a smaller amount of ink and toner than an equal amount of cyan, magenta, and yellow blended together.

Black generation can also be done not just in grayscale areas but for pretty much any color. Any color can have this neutral component where we can use black in instead of using color inks. When we set black generation one of things we set is where black starts. This setting tells the system when it can start using black ink or black toner to output an image. Black ink or toner starting early again can save money and can help with neutrality but, depending upon the size of, especially the droplet of ink on an inkjet printer, in a face and lighter pastel tones, that dark little droplet of black ink can appear to look like graininess, kind of a sand texture, and often if we only have what we call normal black ink or normal black toner, we may want to keep black out of these lighter areas and start black what we call "later" in higher tonal values. If you only have normal ink and a large droplets size on an inkjet printer for example, you may not want to start black somewhere around 50 or 60 percent. The newer inkjet printers have light inks and sometimes very light black inks, and then we can start black earlier, again cutting the cost and providing better control of our neutrals. There you might even be able to start black at 0 because of the very small droplets size of very light black ink that is available.

Before I get to the next sitting, I'm going to talk a bit about something called GCR; gray component replacement which I alluded to a little earlier. This is where we're taking out color ink and replacing it with black ink to cut the cost and to make sure that, especially in neutral areas, that the system stays more neutral. If the cyan, magenta, or yellow colors drift or become a little weaker or a little stronger, and neutrals are made out of mainly black ink, it's not going to matter. It's not going to change the hue of those colors.

I have an illustration here representing one pixel, a red pixel. You can see that it's made up of a lot of magenta and a lot of yellow, but there's also some cyan in there. Often, when you do a conversion that transform from RGB to CMYK you're going to have this third color, a kind of a contaminant color, that's used to increase the density and make it darker. But we can make it darker by using black instead. And, if we look at the amount of cyan, magenta, and yellow, well, that's kind of an equal volume here. That's our neutral density and we can take that out, remove that, and replace it with a lesser amount of a black ink or black toner. This will ultimately give us the same look which is the idea behind gray component replacement. GCR keeps it looking the same but uses less ink, especially less colored ink. On a traditional printing press black ink costs less so GCR gives you an even greater benefit. Those of us using ink jet printers or toner devices, well, it's really the same cost so it doesn't help us there. If I stack these amounts of color, the volume of pigments on top each other, you'll see a little more dramatic difference in the before and after we apply this GCR, the gray component replacement.

In our software when we are building our profile, the black generation is really what the GCR portion is. It is "how aggressive do I want to be in removing color neutral density and replacing it with black"? If you're setting it up using a slider such as the slider in Color Profiler Suite, the farther to the right the more aggressive I'm going to be. And, the more aggressive I am the more black I'm using instead of color.

Going hand in hand with black generation is black width. Black width sets how far away from the pure neutrals we applying the selected amount of black generation, gray component replacement, GCR. The farther to the right we move this slider, the farther away from neutrals we are applying gray component replacement, the black generation.

With black generation and black width both set the left, I'm doing minimal or no black generation and I'm staying right in that neutral axis. But, if I move them all the way to the right, I'm be very aggressive with my black generation and I'm doing it anywhere in color space. To any color in the rainbow I will be applying this black generation.

Black generation allows systems to run better, more neutral, and it reduces our ink usage. If we happen to have a printing press, black generation reduces our ink usage which means that things dry faster, because it reduces the amount of wet ink on paper, we can increase the speed the press, and get more work out. So, there are a lot of reasons for doing gray component replacement, GCR, and again, this is all configured when you build the ICC profile. Ultimately, this should all make sure the output look the same while increasing ink savings, improving productivity, and providing other benefits.

You may notice on some fiery systems, that when you are in the color settings area you have choices that refer Full (Source GCR) and Full (Output GCR). What happens here is the actual transform, going back to our rendering intent discussion, is, for the most part, a relative colorimetric transform. Whenever you have a transform you always have two ICC profiles and, in the case of a source and destination CMYK profile, they both have black generation definitions. If you select full source GCR you are going to use the specification for GCR from the source or the reference ICC profile and, if you select full output GCR it's going to refer to the output, the media profile to pick up the GCR settings to use.

Additional features on the color side that you might find in our RIPs is a setting called either pure primaries in the case of our Fiery driving our toner output devices, or clean color in the Fiery proServer or Fiery XF. The way these work is they'll look at the file coming into the system, and if it has areas, it could be individual pixels or it could be entire graphic elements, that are made up of single primary colors; cyan, magenta, yellow, or black, the system would only use those same specific inks when outputting the file. In the case of red, green, or blue, it might only use a pair of pigments to reproduce the color. For red, it would only use magenta and yellow and not bring in cyan or black. This has the effect of giving you a brighter color output, a little more snap to the output. However, color will likely be less accurate because we're normally color managing those areas but now we are only managing for density but not for true color balance which may give you a better look. You would never use it in a proofing scenario.
title: #Module 8 Video Script#

instruction: Take a moment to review these questions!

_items.title: What is black generation?
_items.body: Black generation refers to a set of options built into the construction of an ICC Profile that determines where black ink or toner is used in image reproduction.

GCR stands for Gray Component Replacement and refers to a calculation used to remove color ink or toner from each individual pixel and replace it with black ink or toner.  This has the effect of reducing ink or toner consumption without altering the color reproduction appearance and is one of the components of black generation.
_items.title: What is GCR?

_items.body: Black start refers to the level where an output device is allowed to start using black ink or toner in image reproduction.  Often, especially if the output device does not have light black colorants available, black is set to start later to ensure that small areas of black ink or toner do not appear in light areas which result in a “grainy” appearance.
_items.title: What does black start refer to?
What is black width?
_items.body: Black width refers to how far away from the neutral axis the system is allowed to apply black generation or GCR.  A very low value would allow the system to apply black generation calculations to neutral or near-neutral elements only while a high value would allow the system to apply this calculation to any element of any color in the document.

title: #Module 8 Review#

body: Which setting would you modify in order to keep small droplets of black ink from appearing in highlight areas?
title: #Module 8 Knowledge Check#

body: Which two options have the most impact on ink or toner usage?

_items.text: Black generation and Total black ink
Black start and Total black ink

title: #Module 8 Knowledge Check Question 2#

body:
We're now going to turn our attention to spot colors, which is the most difficult graphic arts element to reproduce accurately. The reason it's difficult to reproduce accurately is we have sample books from companies such as Pantone, Toyo, DIC, or HKS. These manufacturers, these color library manufacturers, publish books that show what the color should look like. Often they are printed on specialty presses and they're printed on a specific media. And, unless you're printing on that media using the specialty inks you're likely not going to get that particular look.

There is a Pantone book out called the bridge book. The bridge book shows Pantone colors reproduced, again on a specific stock on one side using the ink that is actually that color, and on the other side you can see the color printed on a 4 color press. Some of the colors are very close but some colors are very different. If you are a designer and only look at the at the pretty side of the bridge book but you are going to print four-color, you might be disappointed with the results. The reason we print four-color is because adding that fifth, sixth, seventh, or eighth spot color can become very expensive when using the specialty inks that are mixed to match that specific color plus we need presses that are capable printing more than 4 colors in a single pass.

The library manufactures supply libraries to companies like EFI in the form of L*a*b* values. Remember that L*a*b* mean "what is it supposed to look like". And we call on these L*a*b* values to create the correct color recipe using our ICC profiles that we just learned about in the previous module. The profile converts from the L*a*b*, what it's supposed to look like, to the best recipe it can, picking the correct volumes or amounts of toner or ink that will try to come the closest to that spot color. But, again, the gamut of our output devices is not capable of reproducing the entire spot color library. Our inks are getting better and our output devices are getting better so we're getting closer to encompassing more and more and more of the spot color libraries but there is still a limitation. So, use caution when spot colors are specified.

Your Fiery, Fiery proServer and Fiery XF have the capability of printing samples of swatch books where we can show you what the spot colors will look like on your media on your output device using the inks that you're going to use and then you get a representation of what the spot colors is actually going to look like. It's also possible to do something called optimization. Optimization can be done for spot colors can also be done with process colors the cyan, magenta, yellow, and black, where we will print out samples, measure them with our spectrophotometer, information on which is coming up soon. We'll compare the L*a*b* values we received from what we printed to the reference profiles, SWOP, Fogra 39, Fogra 52, ISO Coated, or the L*a*b* values from the manufacture and, depending upon how far off those L*a*b* values are from each other, we can come up with a correction file that will help improve the color accuracy.

There are a number of things we can do to take control of the reproduction of spot colors but they are, without question, the most difficult to accurately reproduce because we can take a look at that one specific chip and put it right down on that output and see whether we think it's close enough for not. It's a little more difficult to take a fall tree in Vermont with the maple leaves all different colors, and take that swatch and put it into a photograph. Photographs tend to be, by their very nature, much more forgiving than spot colors, but we do have tools to help so check them out in your particular RIP.
title: #Module 9 Video Script#

instruction: Take a moment to review these questions!

_items.body: A spot color refers to a color, used in a design element such as a logo, that is specified as a specific color often using a reference library from a company such as Pantone.  This color can be reproduced using ink mixed to reproduce that specific color using a separate printing plate known as a spot plate on a traditional press, or through a combination of traditional CMYK inks if the color is in-gamut using those inks.
_items.title: What is a spot color?
What does Pantone, DIC, HKS, and Toyo refer to?
_items.body: Each of these refers to a company that develops specific color samples, in the form of libraries that graphic artists can refer to, select, and use in their designs.  Knowing the specific name and library of specific colors in the document, the print provider can refer to the same samples in his or her printed copy of the library to check for visual accuracy.

_items.title: What is a swatch book?
_items.body: A swatch book is a printed display of one or more spot colors.  Library manufacturers print sample swatch books of their color libraries to use as a reference when designing and printing.  In the digital world, custom swatch books can be printed on a specific device using specific customer defined media so that the designer can see exactly how the selected colors will reproduce.

title: #Module 9 Review#

body: Why are spot colors difficult to reproduce accurately?

_items.text: We have no way to accurately measure spot colors
We have no way to accurately measure spot colors
There are no accurate spot color definitions available

title: #Module 9 Knowledge Check#

body: Which Pantone guide should be used to judge the accuracy of spot colors printed on a traditional 4-color printing press?

_items.text: The Pantone Pastel and Textile Guide

body:
In this module will explore the differences between standards and specifications along with their values and limitations. Often, someone will say "well I have to print to a particular standard like Fogra 52 or ISO coated or SWOP." But standard is actually not the correct term; the correct term is a specification. A standard is a little more global; it means what is the product itself.


To look at it a different way a standard would be a car. The car has an engine and it's got wheels. That's the standard. The specification would be what color is it, what size engine, 2 door, 4 door, and what kind of radio.


In our graphic arts world the standard is: it's a printed piece. It's ink or toner on paper and has other criteria that might make up the standard. The specification would be: what is that suppose to look like is it supposed to look like? Fogra 39? ISO uncoated? SWOP 3 or SWOP 5?


The way the specifications are created is, the various manufacturers, various controlling boards, ISO, Fogra or the Idealliance will go to a press site and they will print pieces to conform to a particular quality level they feel they can get on that press, with those inks, and with that media. And the specification is a printed piece but on a particular stock. The final output is measured with a spectrophotometer, and they build an ICC profile that will give us information on what the color is supposed to look like.


Then, if a customer says "well it's supposed to look like Fogra 52 or GRACoL", I could take an ICC profile and select that as the reference profile in our RIP. The RIP is the software that actually drives the output device and often it's what does the final color transform. So we'll take the original file, transform it into this Fogra or ISO or Idealliance color space and then output it so that it simulates that reference.


Simulation of reference is almost always done when we were making proofs. But often in the world of production, people also select a specification that the output should conform to. Well you may want to think twice about that because what we're often doing on our output devices, is we might be throwing away color. We could give the client more color, but we're trying to conform to one of the specifications. And there may be a reason to use a larger specifications, a specification with a larger color space or, there are even ways to print without color management turned on in your output device but still use the calibration portion to take advantage of the entire gamut of the output device. You get our "snappier" output where there's more saturation. It's not as repeatable, bought it can potentially get you better looking output.


Often, however, the customer is saying "well it has to look like something else. We have to match the brochure or we have to match the display or we have to match something else", and then you are locked into conforming to one of the specifications.


Sometimes on certain media, we can't hit that specification. That's what the limitation is. Often, on our media and ink or media and toner combination, the specification is for a particular gamut size and we just don't have the gamut available on that particular combination on our output device. So we have to be a little careful about what we select with our specifications to make sure that we can do a respectable job of trying to hit that color on our output device. But those are the limitations.


Something that has been used quite a bit in North America and also in the Far East is something that is called G7. Now G7 is not a specification. It's not a standard. It's simply a process. It's a method of calibration for traditional printing presses, to get a good gray balance and make sure that the primary and secondary colors, red, green, blue, cyan, magenta, yellow, and black, that's the 7 portion of G7, while the gray balance is the G portion, that they hit specific levels based on, guess what? L*a*b* values. And again, it's just a method of calibrating but in and of itself is not a specification or standard. It's a method you would use to be able to get to one of the specification. If someone says I need it to be G7, well, you need it to be G7 for what? I can use G7 to help you get to a final destination but in and of itself it does not do that.


We have additional materials which you'll see in the reference section of this course, for additional recorded webinars that we've done and materials on a number of the topics explored throughout this course, and a number of them specifically on G7. So, if you're interested in obtaining more information, go take a look.
title: #Module 10 Video Script#

instruction: Take a moment to review these questions!

_items.title: What is a Standard?
_items.body: A standard refers to a high-level definition of a produce such as a car, or a toaster, or a printed piece.  For a printed piece, the standard might include the media that it is printed on and the device that will be used to produce the product.

A specification refers to what the final product, our printed output in this example, needs to look like.  A specification includes information on the color of the media, the color of the 100% solid colors, the color of overprints (e.g. red, green, and blue) as well as the gray balance and the color of tints.  These color specifications are supplied to us from organizations such as ISO, Fogra, and the Idealliance in the form of L*a*b* values.  After printing, a color bar containing these specific color samples are measured with a spectrophotometer and the resulting L*a*b* values are compared to those contained in the Specification.  Delta-E values are generated and the values compared to the tolerance limits contained in the Specification to determine if the printed results are within the tolerance range.  If they are, the output is said to be “in compliance” with the Specification.
_items.title: What is a Specification?

_items.body: Because of the limitations created by differing gamuts on our output devices, it is sometimes not possible to reproduce all of the colors contained within the color space represented by a desired Specification on out output device using the available colorants and media.
_items.title: What are the limitation of using these Specifications?

title: #Module 10 Review#

body: Which of the following is not an industry Specification?
title: #Module 10 Knowledge Check#

body: Fogra 52 is an example of what?
title: #Module 10 Knowledge Check Question 2#

body:
Well, we've just about reached the end of our color fundamentals course. This is the final module and when you complete this module you'll be able to properly select the correct illuminant setting on your spectrophotometer and explain the importance of proper viewing conditions.

This is a handheld+ spectrophotometer, the EFI ES 2000, and there are different what we call a illuminants that can be selected when you take a measurement. This device is used to measure color. It could be my shirt, but, more it will be used to measure a color patch or a color displayed on a monitor. It will measure that color and it will report back the L*a*b* value, what that color looks like to the average observer. When this device is used to measure reflective material it uses a built in light source and also a filtering system. What were filtering for is ultraviolet light in our media.


Often, in the media that we print on, manufacturers add optical brighteners. Optical brighteners are chemical compounds that, when exposed to ultraviolet light which is invisible to the eye, performs a kind of a phase shift and actually bounces it back as visible light and now we see it. So, invisible light hits the printed piece and invisible light becomes visible and bounces back making the media look brighter. It also makes it look bluer, which often is seen as looking whiter. It is less expensive to add optical brighteners than it is to actually manufacture whiter media. The problem is that under different lighting conditions the output will look different. Ultraviolet light is way on the cool end of the spectrum and if there are a lot of optical brighteners in the media, it tends to take on a blue appearance, a very cool look under ultraviolet lighting conditions.


This spectrophotometer has different illuminant capabilities. Earlier spectrophotometers did not and were purchased either with an ultraviolet cutting filter built in that would filter out the effect of ultraviolet light, or no filter and then the effect of the ultraviolet light would come back into the spectrometer and be part of the measurement. The newer spectrophotometers are software controlled and we can measure with or without UV filtering using the same device. These illuminant settings are called M-factors, the most common of which are M0, M1, and M2. M0 uses no filter and let the effect of the UV light come through. M2 is the other end of the spectrum and it filters out all of the ultraviolet light.


In 2009, the standards board got together and said "You know, the lighting conditions that we view products under should have some ultraviolet component in it because often, when reviewing final products out in the real world, there is some ultraviolet light present. It's in an office setting with some daylight light coming in or some other light source that may have some ultraviolet light". If you have a newer light booth, pretty much anything past 2009 or even an old light booth with lamps that were manufactured after 2009, then you might have lamps that produce some ultraviolet light. Those are really M1 lighting conditions. We can set M1 as an option in our spectrophotometer and it will allow some of the ultraviolet component to be part of the measurement. Also, the newer specifications from the Idealliance and Fogra, Fogra 51 and 52 and the new versions of SWOP and GRACoL were all measured using M1 illuminants and exist as M1 data sets. That, now, is the best you can do. Using an M1 reference, an M1 measurement, and an M1 viewing condition. That gives you kind of a complete chain of command or chain of custody from one end to the other. It's kind of makes everything equal. Then, if someone says well it doesn't look good in my office you can say that you view things in an industry standard light booth. You can go back to the same booth time and time again and you will always have the same viewing conditions. These viewing conditions are often referred to D50, a type of daylight viewing condition. If you go to your local hardware store or home improvement store you can buy lamps that indicate that they're daylight or D50 but don't be fooled. Those are not true graphic arts quality lamps and if you use them you still may get a different look.


Because they likely produce a different amount of ultraviolet , or possibly none at all, they're going to give you a different effect and whenever you change from one manufactures daylight bulb to another manufactures daylight bulb, you're likely going to get different results once again. We recommend using a standard graphic arts lame whenever possible. By the way those lamps last alot longer then they're really accurate. They'll produce light for quite some time but, over time, the quality of light will no longer be acceptable. You want to check with manufacturers specifications. Some light booths actually have a clock built it and after x number of hours, you are told that it's time to change the lamps. Then you send them off to the accounting department and they can use them for another year or two but you have lamps that are still conforming to the specification.


So, our spectrophotometer is used to measure color accurately. It gives us L*a*b* values, and we can use the proper illuminant, for example, M1. If everything's M1, M1 is likely the way to go. If you're using one of the older standards, you might want to use M0 no UV filter or if you're just doing pleasing color. M0 with these handheld spectrophotometers allow you to do M0 measurements using one pass through all of your patches versus two passes through each row of patches if you're measuring using M1 or M2.


Well, that completes the course in the fundamentals of color management. Color management itself is a very deep, very rich subject and there is a lot to cover. I've spent almost my entire career studying color management and there are still new things that I learn regularly. We recommend watching other webinars that EFI produces and taking a look at books at the library or at places like Amazon.com or Barnes and Noble. There are a lot of resources and we have listed many of them here in this course but take a look and please continue your study. And don't just go by the theory test. Practice some of this. Make some prints. Try different ways of measuring, different illuminants. Take a look at your output under different lighting conditions. Try different conversion methods. Try different settings and, depending upon your conditions, because no two conditions are the same, and because you know what your customer's needs are, you might find settings that are ideal not only for general work, but maybe for a specific customer because now you have many of the tools, many of the ideas, many of the concepts understood that will allow you to really fine tune your settings for your work, for your materials, or your customer. So continue your investigation, continue your study into the world color management. I wish you luck and thank you for your time.
title: #Module 11 Video Script#

instruction: Take a moment to review these questions!

_items.body: A spectrophotometer is a device that is used to measure color samples and provide the results as L*a*b* values.  It is used when calibrating monitors and output devices and for building ICC Profiles.
_items.title: What is a spectrophotometer?
What is an illuminant?
_items.body: An illuminant refers to a type of light source filtering available on modern spectrophotometers and is used to include, partially, or fully block the effects of ultraviolet (UV) light on media containing optical brighteners.

_items.title: What are optical brighteners?
_items.body: Optical brighteners are chemical compounds added to the media that we print on.  These chemicals react the ultraviolet light in much the same way as does the coating in a fluorescent tube.  Optical brighteners convert invisible UV light into visible light in order to make the media appear brighter and whiter.  The inclusion of optical brighteners reduces the cost of the media when compared to the cost incurred when actually producing a brighter, whiter media.  The problem with optical brighteners is that they alter the appearance of the printed piece when it is viewed under light sources that contain different amounts of UV light such as direct sunlight, office lighting, and a graphic arts viewing booth.

Ideally, you should view final printed pieces in a graphic arts light booth using newer lamps.  The lamps in a light booth change color over time and need to be changed long before they burn out.  By using a light booth, you are adding addition consistency into your evaluation process as opposed to viewing different printed pieces or even the same piece under different lighting conditions in order to determine color accuracy and acceptability.
_items.title: How should I view printed pieces to judge the visual accuracy?

title: #Module 11 Knowledge Check Question 2#

body: Congratulations! You now have all of the fundamental knowledge needed for a firm understanding of the foundational concepts of color management. This brief course did more than scratch the surface of this extensive topic, and it is recommended that you continue your education by completing additional Fiery courses, review documents available at help.efi.com, and read up on the subject by browsing through books on the topic from your local library or available from sites such as amazon.com. And, be sure to practice what you learn. No amount of reading can replace hands-on experience in this powerful field of study.
title: #Summary Page Article Text#

body: Color Management is best described as:

_items.text: a process used in the graphic arts to guarantee perfect color reproduction
a process used to ensure that images appear on different devices in a consistent way
a process for converting black & white images into color images
the process of selecting only reproducible colors
